page.title: 09ST.RADIGUNDS ABBEY BUILDINGS
page.content: The Abbey was built of Caen stone, Kentish ragstone and flints.The 13th century church had a large nave,a choir with north and south transepts, a presbytery and a Lady chapel.The living quarters for the canons consisted of a refectory, kitchen, chapter house,infirmary and large guest quarters.The whole establishment was surrounded with strong stone walls and deep fosses.Two gate houses were built with the main entrance on the north side connecting with woodland tracks to Alkham,Buckland and River. Outside the great fosse were fields tended by the canons and lay workmen. Today the tower of the abbey church is an arched entrance way, the old refectory a mellowed farmhouse and guest quarters a great barn.The many smaller buildings are now outhouses. Cloister ruins remain.
